docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your reference to the 43 million uninsured Americans identifies a serious but misunderstood problem (front page, Sept. 26). Having no insurance does not mean that these patients do not get medical attention. Regrettably, many wait until they have a health crisis, then present themselves to emergency departments, with the tab being picked up by all of us in the form of charity care. That process is highly expensive and very inefficient.
docs.abstract: Letter from James J Barba, president of Albany Medical Center, on problem of 43 million Americans lacking health insurance; holds it is important to get the uninsured assigned to primary-care physicians so that ailments can be treated before they become full-blown crises

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Americans Lacking Health Insurance Put at 16 Percent'' (front page, Sept. 26): Studies have shown that most health care costs arise from only three causes: smoking, obesity, and drug and alcohol abuse. It would be a simple matter to tax the things that are the major sources of sickness to cover the excessive health care costs of those who choose poor health habits. Changing the present system to the single-payer concept to cover the entire population would add additional foolishness. ALAN DONALDSON Idaho Falls, Sept. 26, 1998

docs.lead_paragraph: From the nondescript headquarters of his Houston construction firm, Leo E. Linbeck Jr., a lanky, bow-tied executive with a drawl, is masterminding a crusade to overturn the nation's tax system. Once, someone like him might have hired some of Washington's ''Gucci Gulch'' lobbyists to prowl the well-trod marble corridors outside Congress's tax committees. But Mr. Linbeck, with Texas-style audacity, wants to engineer a populist uprising to replace the income tax code with a national sales tax. And so with $15 million from some initial investors and mass fund-raising, he has run a media advertising campaign and employed an army of consultants, pollsters, political strategists, marketers, academics and yes, even a few lobbyists, to energize the citizenry.

headline.main: A New Form of Lobbying Puts Public Face on Private Interest

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I'm glad Assemblyman Richard N. Gottfried (letter, Sept. 26) wants to take control of health care away from employers, but why does he want government to take over? Why shouldn't we buy health insurance by personal spending out of personal income, the way we get almost everything else we use? Deciding how much consumers want, and how much they are willing to pay for it, is best answered by a free market, not government.

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal officials said today that they were expelling 80 community mental health centers from Medicare after finding that the program to provide psychiatric services to the elderly was riddled with fraud. June Gibbs Brown, inspector general of the Department of Health and Human Services, said that the cost of such care soared to $349 million in 1997, from $60 million in 1993, and that she found that 91 percent of the payments last year were for ''unallowable and highly questionable services.''

headline.main: Cost of Rampant Mental Health Care Fraud Soars in Medicare

docs.lead_paragraph: Some of the hottest, fastest-growing managed health care plans are turning out to be the ones that are hardly managed at all. Unlike health maintenance organizations, which typically try to keep tight control over their members by requiring them to funnel all requests for specialized care through a single doctor, the minimal health plans try to keep costs in check mostly by persuading doctors and hospitals to agree to reduced fees.

headline.main: (Loosely) Managed Care Is in Demand; Provider Plans Zooming Over Restrictive H.M.O.'s

docs.abstract: Popularity of loosely managed medical plans, called preferred provider organizations, or PPO's, is surging, as they take customers away from traditional unlimited fee-for-service plans as well as from more restrictive health maintenance organizations; members of PPO's can go to any doctor without asking permission, although it cost them more to go to physicians and hospitals outside organization's network; as more people reject restrictive HMO's for relative freedom of PPO's, questions arise as to whether quality health care can be delivered at reasonable cost; some HMO's that have tried to compete by being more flexible have run into serious financial trouble; graph; photo (M)
